I want to hear some ideas. Tossing a few out there... "The Tank is Law. You are Crime." "The Tank: Kaleidoscopic Maximalism" "The Heart of a Lion; The Brain ofa Journalism Robot" "Edward R. Murrow Ain't Got Shit On Us" "We Report so You Don't Have To" "Fair and Balanced News, starting in 2026"

Scooter, I demand satisfaction, the kind that can only be had by exposing a mark-ass trick for the trick-ass mark that he is. It has been three days since I posted a very direct and insulting challenge to your comedic abilities, the content of which included disparaging remarks about your flamboyant wardrobe, your lack of skill on the basketball court, and the meaninglessness of your existence. What sort of man is content to sit idly by while his good name is sullied and his honor and sexuality are called into question? Perhaps a few words from William Wallace will help to rouse you from your torpor: "Fight, and you may get played out by Versteeg. Run, and you'll live, albeit under the pseudonym 'Jeff's Little Bitch.' And dying in your bed many years from now, would you be willing, to trade ALL THE DAYS, FROM THIS DAY TILL THEN, TO COME BACK HERE AND TELL STIGGY'S LANKY ASS THAT HE MAY BE FUNNIER, BUT HE'LL NEVER BE MAN ENOUGH TO WEAR A PINK SHIRT!" I tire of this charade, Scoot. Trading snide comments back and forth is a poor substitute for a true match of wits. So pick a topic by Monday or you'll never hear the end of it.

(Fuck you Scooter - don't take away my Africa angle - it's the only thing I've got.) South Africans love Pac. Every time the gas station attendant hears that we are from America, he starts rappin' Pac and asking about Hollywood. Part of this is simply timing - Tupac reached the height of his popular appeal right around the time when South Africa was undergoing its democratic transition. Since so much ofthe revolutionwas expressed musically anyway, Tupac was lionized here as some sort offreedom fighter. His movie, Tupac Resurrection,gets huge play here and has made tons ofmoney. Well, good for him, butPac was no revolutionary. He wasn't even a goodrapper- instead he was asmall-time thug, a hack who wore the trappings of a ghetto warrior but in reality was just another fake ass MC. Tupac's sole source ofblack power street cred came from his moms being aBlack Panther. That is like mesaying thatI have a special relationship withGod because my dad is a preacher. But I ain't got shit on God, andPac don't have shit on black power. Let me remind you that thisguy got started as a groupie for Digital Underground. Picture himcoming on stage at a DU concert, jumping around like an idiot in the background witha Mr. PotatoHead nose on. And then, ten years later, he's converting toIslam and acting all hardcore like he'sSaid from Oz. Keep it real Pac - thiswould be like ifwe found out that Malcolm X got his start answering phones for the Al Sharpton presidential campaign. Kind of damaging. AndTupac's day in court? He played like he was a freedom fighter getting persecuted by the authorities. Clones were outside holding up "Free Tupac" signs like he wasLeonard Peltier or something. What did he get arrested for? Sedition? Protesting the court's treatment of ghetto youth?Try taking a swing at a local rapper with a baseball bat during a concert. Oh, and he got arrested one other time after that too - for sexually abusing anineteen year old girl with three friends.Yeah you're a real hero Pac. He was dirty fucker too - before they filmed Poetic Justice, Janet Jackson insisted that Pac get an HIV test before they did any kissing scenes. Then in '95, hesupposedly renounced the "thug life" in an interview from his jail cell. He alsopointed thefinger at Biggie, Puffy, and a couple of his friends for attacking him in a hotel lobby.So he's gone clean, andas his first good deed he rats a bunch of people out. Sounds like astraight sellout to me. How about keeping your mouth shut and donating the proceeds of your quintuple platinum record deal to charity? So there you have it - Pac was a sellout and a mark-ass buster. And those songs he released to try to show his soft side (Dear Mama, Brenda's got a baby, Changes)? They all sucked andthe rhymes were weak.Tupac sold image, not talent on the mic, and even that wasa complete fake. He studied ballet atBaltimore School of the Arts for chrissakes. The best thing that ever happened to him was getting shot, otherwise he would have been exposed for the fake-ass MC he really was. Word life I'm out

Y Point-Counterpoint Well, weâre coming up on the beginning of another school year and invariably our thoughts must turn to academic rebirth - to the new year and the exciting new recruits it will bring to campus. And no, sports fans, Iâm not talking about your football teams. Iâm talking about the incoming class of impressionable young girls. Freshman coeds are one of the main ingredients in the socio-sexual smorgasbord we call college and there are a couple of blue-chip prospects out there who have signed their letters of intent and are ready to saddle up. Iâm referring, of course, to the Olsen twins, who are set to matriculate at NYU in the fall. What two 18-year-old millionaires hope to gain from college- other than 30 pounds and an exhaustive knowledge of fraternity basements- is beyond us, but the Tank prides itself on keeping its finger placed firmly on the pulse of young America and this is a hot-button issue. So management trundled down to the basement and presented the Point-Counterpoint Department with this resolution: You want the Olsen twins at your school. Pro Are you kidding me? I havenât seen a slam dunk like this since they found the bloody glove. But a bucket is a bucket and Iâve got a couple minutes to spare on this one. There are about a million reasons to want Michele Tanners doodling away next to you in Psych 101, Iâll just reel off a few of the most important. 1. You might hook up with them. First of all, yes I said THEM. Not one. Them. One of the most important and fundamental laws of this universe is that twins are a package deal. Two for one. Buy one, get one free. You do not have to deal with them as separate people, individuals with unique hopes and desires and dreams. Twins are freaks and can be treated as such. You get a twin on the line and youâre eating double that night. Second, yes I said YOU. This is not a humor magazine for stuck-up royalty or trustifarians or those damned Eurotrash male models. This is the Tank. Normally, the Olsens are the exclusive domain of all those jerk-offs I just mentioned. Thatâs the way it goes with celebrities. But take them out of Beverly Hills and take away their publicists and agents, and what youâre left with is a couple of 18-year-old girls going to college. You know what that means? At that point the playing field is leveled. Theyâre on your turf. They will drink to excess. They will take drugs. They will feel insecure. They will feel ugly. They will be willing to make a mistake. All you have to do is be in the right place at the right time. Advantage: Tank reader. 2. Little things are funnier when celebrities do them. Our celebrity-worshipping society often makes it seem like the rich and famous are not subject to the daily inconveniences and embarrassments suffered by us mere mortals. This is of course not true, but it creates just enough cognitive dissidence to make the idea funny. Me waiting in line at the DMV and cussing out the clerk? Frustrating and somewhat inappropriate. Robert DeNiro in the same situation? Hilarious. Me getting punked out by some girl at the bar? Funny. Hurtful, but funny. Substitute Freddy Prinze, Jr.? I just peed my pants. You get the idea. Well, college is filled with tons of those little embarrassing moments that we all take for granted. Now imagine if you could up the ante by having celebrities around for all of them. Watching a girl stumbling back home at 9:30 on a Saturday morning with tussled hair and disheveled clothing is funny. It is way funnier if that girl is the Olsen twins. Olsen twins inventing lame excuses for turning their papers in late. Olsen twins caught cheating on a mid-term. Olsen twins pigging out at two in the morning at Taco Bell. Olsen twins puking at the Delta Chi mixer. Funny when itâs you. Funnier when itâs them. 3. These two are ready to go ballistic. Iâve already heard rumors from my boys in NYC that people have gone into parties and seen the Olsen twins doing blow. Outrageous. That sight alone would be worth the price of admission. Ashley is anorexic. Mary Kate is an addict. Or the other way around. Or they both are both. Who cares? The semester hasnât even started yet and these two are making headlines. You know how itâs fun to be friends with the real rich girl who parties all the time and throws around tons of cash? Well these girls are billionaires and itâs their money. The parties will be hot. The champagne will be flowing. The girls will be easy. The twins have been coddled and protected and micromanaged their whole lives. They are fixing to explode. If theyâre at your school, pull up a chair, crack open a beer and get ready. Even from the cheap seats, the view will be spectacular. Con Moby Dick. I guess that bookâs supposed to be about manâs search for God or truth or himself...some garbage like that. Go ask the guy behind the counter at Starbucks. I was an economics major and to me that book is just about some asshole wasting his whole life hunting around for a damned white whale. Ahab probably could have gotten a lot of good things done with his life were it not for his fishing addiction. Feeding the hungry. Sheltering the homeless. Loving his women. Iâm just riffing here. The thing is, I donât really blame him. You show a whaler the biggest gastropod heâs ever seen â and the beast is white as the driven snow â and heâs gonna get obsessed. He just canât help himself. The solution is to never let him catch a glimpse of Moby Dick. Minus that burden, Ahab is a successful businessman, a devoted husband and father, and a community leader. Also the whole crew doesnât die and that wicked dude Queequeg is still kicking it. A rosy picture if not for that damn whale. Why do I bring this up? Because if you get the Olsen twins at your school, youâre gonna waste all your time chasing a white whale. College could be a time of great fun and learning and growth. Or you could at least lose yourself in a wash of drunken days and dreamless nights. You start traipsing around after Hollywood eye-candy and youâll end up just like Ismail: all alone and lost in the world with nothing but a coffin to bury yourself in. Maybe you just fail a couple classes and graduate a semester late. Point is, chasing after the Olsens is a zero sum game. What exactly do you hope to accomplish? You think youâre gonna score? Look at yourself. Taking a swing at the driving range doesnât make you a PGA golfer and a couple of awkward, fumbling, alcohol-inspired advances do not make you a lothario. These young ladies have been hit on by the cream of the crop. Weâre talking famous actors, jet-setting businessmen, landed aristocracy. Something tells me that a 19-year-old marketing major with good pot connections and every episode of The Family Guy on DVD is not gonna cut it. I recommend trolling after whatever comes out of the frat houses around 2:30 and being grateful for anything you get. You think theyâll be your friends? Please re-read the previous paragraph. What do you think youâre bringing to the table? A good sense of humor. Loyalty. Maybe youâre a good listener. Or a nice person. Celebrities donât care about these things. You better have mad loot, access to mad loot, a talk show, established and dependable media connections, a new movie coming out, or truckloads of cocaine if you want to join this party. Wait, though, you have a big heart and an honest soul and the Olsens are sure to see past all the superficiality in the world and find out that the things that really matter in this life donât cost a dime, donât cost anything at all, in fact, except an open mind and a willingness to trust. I oughta smack you in the mouth. This is not a Hilary Duff movie. You are not famous. You are not rich. You will not be their friend. F$# the Olsen twins, you say? All you wanna do is hang around and get in on some fun times? This is by far the most dangerous way to think precisely because it seems the most reasonable. You know they want nothing to do with you and youâre fine with that. You donât particularly want anything to do with them. You just want a little of their fame and fortune to trickle itâs way down to you. Maybe you luck into one sweet party they throw and it will all be worth it. Wrong. While youâre off on your wild-goose chase, the Olsens will be at a private club or in a private plane or at the Playboy mansion...basically all the places you donât have the power or the pull to even approach. They donât go to dive bars or frat houses or house parties. Theyâre like Keyser Soze. By the time you even get a whiff of them, theyâre gone. Donât be too hard on yourself. Itâs normal to think this way. Itâs probably what anyone of us would do in your place. And thatâs why you donât even want the chance to screw up. Remember how much better off Ahab would have been if heâd never seen that hump like a snowhill. Now think about that every time you wish Mary Kate and Ashley were playing quarters in your dorm room.

Alright Scooter, it's clear that you want a piece of me after I made that crack about your sister. I propose that we settle this like men - on the basketball court. Syke! Take it easy tubby, raining dunks on your head won't solve anything. If your shit is really that funny, let's do a point-counterpoint and let the people decide. Just like in poker, I'm willing to give you a big handicap. We'll write about any topic of your choice, and you get to pick your side. Anything is fair game - the merits of pink clothing for men, the merits of wearing pink clothing to attract other men, whether or not wearing pink clothing helps you meet girls because they assume that you're gay, etc. You're in the driver's seat. Any ideas for topics from the rest of you guys are welcome. I would only request that for the sake of having a balanced competition, please try to come up with subjects that are of little or no importance, so that Scoot Dogg will have a chance to compete with me on a somewhat equal footing. Britney vs. Jessica, whether or not it's cool to stand in the TRL line, favorite cast member of Queer Eye for the Straight Guy , these are the sorts of issues to go with.

So I went to go see Mean Girls last week. I think it's been out for a while - we're kind of behind here though. One of the funny things about seeing movies here is that most people don't really get the jokes, and laughs come at odd times. But I digress. Because I am in campaign season mode, this "movie" review will be making liberal use of scare quotes as a cheap form of sarcasm. I call Mean Girls a "movie", however, because a movie implies a viable plot and a story. Let's face it though, "movies" like this are less stories than wistful paeans to a certain vision of a nostalgic time of life for many people, stitched together by a few jokes. The success of such a "movie" is ultimately judged by how much the audience agrees with its particular view of the high school experience. The plot is just window dressing. Speaking of window dressing, the "movie" stars Lindsey Lohan as the new girl in town. Her parents are field zoologists, and so she had spent all of her life up to this point in Africa, as a homeschool student. This turns her into a kind of natural experiment for what high school can do to a normal, stable person. She doesn't understand that she is extremely hot, and has never had a boyfriend. You see, in Africa, none of the boys pay attention to her. Nucka please. I happen to know a thing or two about Africa now, and one thing I know for sure is that they LOVE white girls down here. Especially ones with - ahem - curves. Which brings me to another point - I don't know how old Ms. Lohan is in real life, but in the movie she is sixteen. There's something slightly discomfiting about this, for she is very clearly a sex object, but kind of disarmingly cute at the same time. I can imagine that men watching this movie can't decide whether they want to deflower her or make sure she gets home by midnight. How much conflict you feel over this depends entirely on how old and how sleazy you are. Let's just say that I don't have to think too hard about it, but if you think I'm uncomfortable, check out Roger Ebert. This has been happening with other teen princesses like the Olsen twins and Hilary Duff for a while now, but the discomfort is always manageable. Why does Mean Girls raise the bar? I can distinguish Lindsay Lohan from Hilary Duffin two words - BOOBIES. As usual, SNL cronyism makes its presence felt. Happily though, this movie manages to avoid the annoyingly desperate, please-give-me-my-own-movie SNL appearance, in favor of some smart and inspired choices - well, mostly just Tim Meadows as the school principal. He plays it so understated that it works, and he ends up owning some of the best lines in the "film". I'm not sure why it was so funny. My buddy thought it was because he was "acting white", but I don't think that's it. To me, Tim Meadows is like that joke that started off being funny, then got real old and played out, but kept going and going until eventually it became funny all over again.This guy has been plugging away for so long that hismere presence inspires laughter, especially when heeschews that cheap gagthat you thought he was going for. Kudos to you, Tim, for realizing that your comedic prowess now relies primarily on self-caricature. Another notable SNL appearance was Ana Gasteyer as the mom. It was notable, though, only because her role was not in any way comedic. It's not that she made bad jokes, just that her role was totally serious - kind of weird. But back to the story. So of course on the first day of school, she hooks up with the fat gay guy and the goth girl that everyone thinks is a lesbian. Big surprise. And of course they are secretly the coolest and most down-to-earth people in school, even though everyone thinks they are nerds. Let me take the time out to explode the myth, popularized by the teeming host of "high school experience" movies, that the nerds in high school are really the coolest and most successful later in life.Not true. Nerds are nerds are nerds - ain'tnothing you can do to change it, including being rich and successful. As an example, let's take hip hop impresario Sean "P Diddy" Combs. Successful producer,occasional rapper, entrepreneur,founder of Bad Boyrecords, incredibly rich, dated J-Lo, big fucking dork. What does he spend his money on? White gloves and servants who carry parasols over him while he walks.Lame.Don't ever forget that when Sean was in high school, he was that kidat the talent show tap-dancing and getting booed the fuck off the stage. I guarantee you that he never recovered from the nerd-scarring of that experience. Case in point: his much celebrated nicknames. Not exactly hard-core, are they? "Puff Daddy"? "P Diddy"? The theme went from Pokemon to Donkey Kong, the sure footprintof a nintendo nerd. Now normally Demington applauds old-school Nintendo references, but if PuffDiddy was cool, he would call himself something sweet like Kid Icarus, or MC Tecmo Super Bowl. So the chesty Ms. Lohan hatches a plan with the embittered lesbian to invade the group of popular girls, known as the "Plastics", and then sabotage ---- actually, forget it. The rest is predictable. Which is not to say that it's bad - the movie was pretty funny actually.But who am Ikidding -my reasons for seeing this movie had nothing to do with the plot (which wandered around like George Michael's eyes at aTurkishbathhouse) andeverything to dowith a set of bodaciousya-yas. I think that's why my roomie wanted to go see it too, but we didn't really talk about it. Probably because we share a bedroom.

Top Ten Crappiest TV Shows of All Time 10) Curb Your Enthusiasm - You know, I really wanted to like this show, and I did, for about four or five episodes. Then I realized that this show is the sitcom equivalent of a madlibs book - it follows the exact same formula every week. Larry gets into disagreements with people by being an asshole or being misunderstood or whatever, these disagreements invariably escalate into an extremely awkward situation, and in the end, his life is just as miserable and pathetic as it was half an hour ago. Granted, the show has brought us some great characters, such as a rapper who loves cunnilingus (a white guy definitely wrote that episode) and a former porn star who rose to fame in the industry by maintaining his erections with a dab of hot sauce in his anus. Nonetheless, it's up to Larry to make or break the show, and after watching a full season on DVD, I concluded that he annoys the shit out of me just as much as he annoys everyone else on the show. 9) The O'Reilly Factor - Truly, Billy Boy gets the nod here on behalf of the entire Fox News network. The smug, haughty tone in which the "news" is delivered on this channel makes me want to punch most of the Fox newsmen in the face. The O'Reilly Factor makes the list because I want to punch Bill O'Reilly in the face after having kicked him in the testes. Seriously, why does this jerkoff even have guests on his show? If you're going to shout people into submission before they can even finish a sentence, why not just deliver a 30 minute monologue? That's clearly what this egomaniac would prefer, but unfortunately, he must sometimes tolerate guests whose opinions differ from his own so that Fox News can continue billing its programs as "fair and balanced." This moral crusader, who loves to get up on his high horse with people, made a name for himself in the industry by dishing the dirt on Inside Edition , and has recently written a trashy novel. For his next book, maybe he could write one about a right-wing ideologue talk-show host who is forced into hiding after being repeatedly kicked in the testes by angry viewers. 8) Superbowl Halftime â Even Janet Jacksonâs droopy little right breast couldnât keep this perennial loser from making the list. Every single year, a ton of money is put into this show to attract the biggest stars and set up cool pyrotechnics and stuff, yet it always manages to suck. Maybe itâs because everyone is tuned into this game to see football, not pre-pubescent popstars. Couldnât we squeeze an Arena Football game in at halftime or something? As if this show werenât disappointing enough on its own, the âcostume malfunctionâ at this yearâs Superbowl Halftime has created a wave media censorship that would make Stalin proud. You know a show has gotten really bad when it threatens to end free speech as we know it. 7) Last Call with Carson Daly - TRL did not make my list, but only because Carson Daly is too boring for me to write more than one paragraph about how boring he is. I don't understand how it's possible to spend all of your time hanging out with incredibly hip people, yet be so stiff and out of touch yourself. This guy has the personality of a 10th grade algebra teacher. It was one thing to be boring on TRL , because there was a lot of T and chicks screaming and a video every once in a while. On Last Call, though, it's justCarson and whatever B-list celeb was desperate enough for publicity to endure the Chinese water torture of having a ten-minute conversation with him. The only explanation I can come up with is that this guy is the bastard son of some network exec, and to keep it quiet he had to give his unwanted progeny a shot at the big time. Well, enough is enough, dad, you'll never make filet mignon out of this rump roast, just like you'll never erase the stain of illegitimacy. Give it up. 6) COPS â Thereâs a reason that I donât live in a bad neighborhood, and itâs because I donât want to be around low-down people all the time, especially when theyâre acting crazy and doing dumb shit. Why is it so entertaining to watch a crack addict being chased by the cops? Donât people have anything better to do with their time than to watch the police play marriage counselor for white trash couples? If you need to watch a show about people who are losers to boost your self-esteem, at least watch Jerry Springer . Heâs going to be the governor of Ohio someday, so you might as well find out where he stands on issues like fathering a child with your best friendâs transsexual wife. 5) VH1 - A few years ago, the clones at VH1 had two revelations - people like countdowns, and people like to relive old memories. Today, any show that is aired on this network must be in one of these two formats, or some combination of both. If this is all they have to offer, why not just call it MTV Classic instead of VH1? As if it wasnât bad enough to keep rehashing the same tired old clips, VH1 has recruited an army of quasi-celebrities to crack jokes about how ridiculous hair metal was or how weird Michael Jackson is. A note to up-and-coming comedians - making obvious and oft-repeated comments about entertainers who actually made it in the business is not a career. Nobody is going to give your ass a sitcom because they saw you making fun of Vanilla Ice. Oddly enough, VH1 plans to become even more incestuous and unoriginal by doing new shows that rehash their old shows. Pilot ideas currently being batted around by top management include 100 Most Metal Moments of 100 Hottest Hotties and I Love I Love the 80s . 4) Sportscenter (1998-present) - Sportscenter checks in at number four not because it is a bad show today, but because it has fallen so far from where it used to be. The current incarnation of the show is sleek, polished, and pretty much indistinguishable from every other sports news show out there. But once upon a time "The Center," as it was affectionately dubbed by the true believers, delivered tomfoolery, laugh-out-loud-funny commentary, and heart, along with up-to-the-minute news and scores. Patrick, Olberman, Kilborn, and sometimes Kenny Mayne blended comedy and sports into a smooth and hilarious cocktail that I would imbibe three or four times daily. Nowadays, I'm lucky to let loose even a chuckle while watching this show, let alone a side-splitting howl or hearty guffaw. A few words for the phonies that have ruined what was once my favorite show - Matt Winer, you're a robot. Trey Wingo, having a funny name may get you your own commercial, but it doesn't get you any cred with me. Linda Cohn, I know they need a token woman in that frathouse, but whenever you try to be funny it gives me the same sort of feeling that I got when my parents tried to talk to me about sex. 3) Real Sex - Speaking of sex, this show covers a lot of topics that my parents didn't get around to telling me about, like how much fun it is to discover wife swapping in your old age, or why it's important to treat yourself to a prostitute after being incarcerated for a long time. I know HBO has made a lot of these, but seriously, who the hell is watching? It's not pervs looking for whack-off material, because there is precious little nudity on this show, and what scraps they do throw your way are barely enough make Sergeant Peter stand at attention. It's not couples trying to improve their sex lives - you could find more useful information about having a good romp in the sack in the pages of Maxim . Maybe HBO just wanted to build their reputation as a cutting-edge, provocative network. If so, then here's some advice - create a reality show where you film good-looking people while theyâre on the job. And stop fooling me into thinking there's going to be some sex on this show, God dammit! 2) America's Funniest Home Videos - Beware of any show that proclaims itself the "funniest" anything - much like Real Sex , the title of this show is highly misleading. I guess it's sort of comical to see an infant farting out a cloud of baby powder, or to watch some little bastard spit out the candles on his birthday cake, but is that the best this country can do? I mean, a lot of the people in these videos are not only not funny, they are total losers, and theyâre giving America a bad name. This show could more accurately be titled âWhite Trash Americaâs FunniestHome Videos.â Or maybe that was COPS. Anyway, what about Bob Saget - he was a huge star when this crap was on the air! You would think that since he was already on Full House , the cheesiest show on TV, it would have been prudent not to put all of his eggs into one cheesy basket. But thatâs exactly what he did, and now no one will ever take him seriously when he talks about sucking dick for cocaine. Hey Bob, here's a funny home video that will put you back on the map - use your connections from Full House to get some footage of the Olsen twins blowing lines and making out with each other. 1) Saved by the Bell â Perversely enough, I have probably watched this show more times in my life than any other (except for Seinfeld ). Why would I faithfully watch a show that I hate? Hey, fat girls need love too. But seriously, this show always managed to be on right after school when I was feeling bad about not participating in extracurricular activities. It made me feel better about my boring life, because here were these good-looking kids on TV, clearly the popular kids in school, and they were just as boring as I was! How many shows have you seen that are all about adolescents yet tackle none of the issues of adolescence? The writers on Saved by the Bell would have you believe that most people come of age while standing around by their lockers and eating greasy food at the Max. Where was the sex? Slater and Jesse dated for like six years on that show. He called her âMama.â One does not call a girl âMamaâ unless one has less than noble intentions for her tall skinny ass. Many believed he would pursue Olympic dreams. âScott loved to skate,â says early childhood friend Brendan Massini. âHe thought he just looked soo cute in that tutu.â Only the ridicule of his peers kept Scott from a career on the ice, though he also expressed a dislike for the heavy figure skates themselves, preferring a profession where lighter, more stylish loafers would be de regour. Stones by a river are smooth. And while Iâm on the subject, theyâre also dull, lifeless and covered in mud. The sad thing is these stones werenât always in such a stateâ¦they began as rocks with distinct shapes and textures. But alas, once these rocks were engulfed by the river, the waters eroded their features until they were as smooth as a smooth stones. The river my friends is the world in which we live. If you stay in the river too long, the current will rip away all that is unique and special, and leave you an undifferentiated shell of a man. Thatâs the bad news. The good news is that we jumped in the river, and we can jump right on out. I jumped in the river about two years ago when I started working at Procter Gamble, and stopped writing. As somebody who is completely submerged in the river, I can report that it is cold, harsh, and full of money. As much as I would like to leave the river, I donât think I could live without the ability to afford the extra super deluxe cable package. Iâm so happy that Aaron took the initiative to start a blog to get everyone writing again. Iâve been looking for an opportunity to get out of the river by writing again, and seeing your hilarious posts will get me back in the game. I promise to write something less depressing in the very near future, but I just needed to get this off my chest to the only people that would truly understand just how amazing it can feel to stand on a cliff high about the river.

In response to Bruns' response to me, here's Y's Top Ten TV Shows of All Time 10. Dr. Katz, Professional Therapist Some people will cry like little babies about squigglevision, but take some dramamine and sack up, the show is hilarious. Essentially a forum for comedians to do snippets of their act while sitting on the shrink's couch, Dr. Katz really wins with the interplay between the good doctor and his son, Ben. The guest comedians are an eclectic mix of early stars, fringe players and no names. Dead pan never tasted so good. Also, just about the only thing going on Comedy Central before it blew up in the late nineties. 9. Cheers I loved this show when it was on, but I was a little worried that like Thunder Cats and the Transformers before it, my good childhood memories would be sorely disappointed by adult viewings. Why was I ever concerned? Cheers is as funny to me now as it was when I was 12 (and I probably get all the jokes now, too). Terrific ensemble, great writing, great characters, makes you laugh out loud. Also, amazing to think they got Kirstie Alley to be a sex symbol. 8. SportsNight I hate nothing more than stealing one of Bruns' takes, but when you're right, you're right. SportsNight was a great, no laughtrack comedy cut down way before it's prime. Sorkin's trademark dialogue works perfectly in the world of television sports, which is where intelligent smart-ass types should end up anyway. Did anyone else think Natalie was hot? 7. The Shield New show that doesn't get a lot of attention from most of my peers, but it is outstanding. It is a hard, cold world out there and the Shield reminds us of that every week. Short seasons keep the writing fresh and we are rewarded with terrific characters and excellent performances all around. Special bonus for resurrecting the Commish as the straight nastiest character on TV. 6. Twin Peaks Man, a large part of me wanted to put this one right up at the top of the list. I love this show. I used to show up to high school unshowered and sleepy-eyed after staying up all night watching the Twin Peaks marathon on Bravo. I couldn't get enough of any of it. Unfortunately, as tends to be the case with something as cool and out-there as this, they just couldn't keep it up. Things really went nuts at the end of the second season and the wheels fell off the wagon. But while it was on, there was nothing better. Damn fine cup of coffee. 5. Homicide: Life on the Streets Best network drama ever in my estimation and probably the most underrated show while it was on the air (with the possible exception of #1 on my list). A mid-nineties show, it got shoved out of the limelight by lesser shows like Law and Order, NYPD Blue, and ER. Those pieces of crap couldn't hold Homicide's jock. Yaphey Kotto. Ned Beatty. The fat Baldwin brother. Gripping stories every week, great guest stars, and the amazing performance of Andre Braugher as Det. Frank Pembleton, which should have won him the Emmy every single year. Fortunately, part of the team behind it got another chance (see my #1). 4. The Simpsons Ah, the Simpsons. In college, when I was at Swarthmore, me and a buddy of mine wanted to create a travelling Simpsons' trivia team that would go to other colleges and compete against like-minded dorks. We would have crushed. The last, well really the last 5 or 6 seasons have been hit or miss, but so what? We don't remember Willie Mays stumbling around with the Mets. Or Hank Aaron hitting weak flies for the Brewers. We remember them as the crushers they were for so long. And so it should be with the Simpsons. So funny for so long and the forerunner for all the great animation cartoons we have today. And, quite frankly, probably the originator of 60% of the funny things I say. 3. South Park Three years ago I would have slapped you in the face if you had even suggested South Park would be in my top ten. But times change and people grow and I can only say that I am sorry that it took me so long to get on the bandwagon. Sick takes on current political and social events. Laugh out loud bathroom humor. Taking it to celebrities. A great cast of characters. And Cartman, who in a couple years I might be willing to argue is the funniest television character ever. The scary thing is, I think they might just be getting warmed up. 2. Seinfeld I don't know if I really even have to say anything about this choice. The only thing I'll add is that about five years ago, I read an article suggesting that Frasier would hold up much better in reruns than Seinfeld. The author felt that Frasier was all about classical humor - farce and slapstick and wordplay - stuff that was funny when Shakespeare did it and would be funny even after the machines have taken over. Seinfeld, on the other hand, was topical. It made fun of issues people faced in the '90s, but would cease to be funny when people stopped facing those issues. Well, when was the last time you watched a Frasier rerun? The thing the author didn't realize is that all the little stuff Seinfeld put on the table - annoying acquaintences, insecurities about the opposite sex, masturbation - are timeless. This was just the first show to put them at the forefront. My grandkidswill belaughing at the reruns. 1. The Wire What? The Wire? I've never heard of that. Wait, isn't that the one on HBO? I don't get HBO. Well, pry your wallet open, Scrooge, pull out the $5/month and subscribe. The Wire (and mind you, this is after only two seasons) is the best show in the history of television and second place isn't even really close. From the creative team that brought me #5 on my list, The Wire deals with the drug trade in Baltimore. Andthe police investigating them. Andcorruption surroundingthe stevedores union. And local politics. It is the realest show on TV, dealing out the raw truth about race and justice and life. Its non-episodic format cause some ofour dimmer viewers confusion, but f 'em, fine wine wasn't made for the masses. The best written, most intricately planned show I know, like watching a novel over the course of three months.If you're not watching this one, you might as well throw out your TV. Addendum I'd like to give a quick shout out to some of my favorite shows that didn't quite make the list. I love all the dramas HBO does, but Six Feet Under, Carnivale, Deadwood, and even the Sopranos have a little more work to do to get into the top 10. (On the other hand, I find HBO's comedies to be highly overrated, especially Curb Your Enthusiasm, but especially Sex and the City). I loved Bruns' Quantum Leap take, that was my show back in the day. I caught it for a while on Sci-Fi a couple years back, though, and it just didn't hold up. Family Guy is great, but now that they're bringing it back I thought it smarter to wait and really evaluate it fully then. Also like the SNL take....almost feel like that one belongs in its own category. King of the Hill also deserves a big hand, severely underrated and I'm afraid misunderstood by a lot of people. Mike Judge does everything well. Mystey Science Theater 3000 was also a favorite in its day, though you can only watch so many in short order. Finally, to my favorite reality show and a special shout-out to Scoooter, Joe Schmo, where they are pushing it every week. I'm out. Wait, one more addendum. I know I have not even mentioned a lot of shows that people just a little bit older than my might love. Too bad. I never watched 'em and I never will. This is my top ten and I got no room for the oldies.

Larry Bird, who carried the Boston Celtics to three NBA championships, is one the game's greatest players ever. His name will be remembered alongside the sport's best, forever immortalized in the pantheon of basketball heros. But for me, I will always remember Larry Bird as an A-1, cream-of-the-crop wangsta. Was Bird really that good? His main competition at the time was an Uncle Tom from Michigan State who called himself "Magic." How gay is that? Not that "Earvin" is much better. Oh yeah, and the guy had the Hiv. He was so busy banging groupies -- and probably high school boys point guards -- that it was a wonder he had time to shoot a layup. Why do people think Bird was such a good guy? Because he's a well-raised, old-fashioned country boy from Indiana? No way, partner. Players always talk about how Bird was Notorious A-H.O.L.E. He yelled at his teammates, cussed people out to their faces, dogged out people he didn't like and called out other players in the media. Larry Bird loved Larry Bird. "Yeah, but he never would have done something like choke P.J. Carlissimo," hoops purists complain. No, probably not. He probably would have killed him. Next, Bird was boring. Can you drop a nasty dunk? No. How about a nasty crossover? Not really. You don't even have shoes named after you, do you? Of course not. Why? Because all you could do was shoot and pass and maybe dribble OK. If Bird was around today he would probably ride the pine behind Wally Szczerbiak. And the other players would DEFINITELY laugh at him. I am guessing Bird doesn't even have any God-given talent. He is just tall. In Indiana there is nothing else to do besides tip cows, so he just sat around all day and shot the basketball. Real impressive. If Deming had grown up on a farm, he probably would own the NBA scoring record by now. Plus, players from the country get immensely strong because they have to bail hay and till the land as youths. That is why baseball players of olden times are better than the players of today (Youngner and Schmidt, 1996*). Also, Bird gives false hopes to many young, impressionable white kids who now think they have a legitimate shot at making the NBA. Riiiiight. The NBA is for black athletes only and for wiggas like Jason Williams. And goofy foreigners like Dirk Nowitzki and Pao Gasol -- but they don't count. I guess Steve Nash and Jason Kidd might be exceptions, but if want endorsements you are out of luck, Steve Kerr. And finally, and this is the most upsetting thing about Bird, is how Goddamned ugly he is. Seriously, he is a funny-looking man. It looks like somebody ran his face over with a steamroller, and then grabbed his ugly mug by the nose and tried to strectch it back out again. He has no chin, there is no doubt about that. Bird was a huge star, one of the game's greats. And yet he probably single-handedly disproved the universal truth that if you are a star in the National Basketball Association, you will get tons of hot-girl poontang. Bird would probably rather milk a cow. Larry Bird, one-on-one with Gerald Wilkens? My money's on the G-Man. He signed on with the Cavs to stop Air Jordan.
